comments.comment: @2:50 This might sound a little confusing. These "waves of propagation" travelling at up to 5 miles per second - about 23.5 times the speed of sound (speed of sound in dry air ...) - are propagating through the earth's crust. The water waves (fastest in the deep ocean) may reach speeds of around 500 mph (a little over 8 miles per minute - about 2/3 times the speed of sound).  That is crazy-fast.

comments.comment: 1:25 Hello NatGeo. I'd just like you to know that tectonic plates are ALWAYS pushing together. What creates the earthquakes are energy after tension is released, like a rubberband being stretched before releasing (except the energy building up is from external/outward friction of two independent elements). Edit: That's also why the quakes have different magnitudes, and some areas experience larger than others in general - because of the shapes on the tectonic plates.  Would appreciate it if you didn't spread misinformation.
